text: EVERYTHING...every food product needs to have a full disclosure label. It IS our RIGHT to know what we are purchasing and consuming.

Please use established terms and print the disclosure details on the packaging so we can see upfront what we are getting. The proposed labeling is misleading, and therefore unacceptable.

text:
As someone with a Seizure, Hearing and Mobility Service Support Dog, I would like to comment on the impending changes to the Air Carrier Access Act (ACAA). The primary issues faced by both people with disabilities, airline staff and the traveling public can be summed up and efficiently addressed by changing the ACAA definition of service animal to mirror that in the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). This definition does not encompass animals that are not task-trained and public access trained to assist someone with a disability. Such a definition also places responsibility for the animals behavior in the moment directly with the person to whom it is associated, not through elaborate validation schemes.

My service dog performs counter balance support, so he is a larger dog. Regarding species and size of service animals, I recommend that the ACAA follow the ADA in defining species of service animals. Large dogs like mine are often required to handle the needs of people with specific disabilities and I encourage the airline industry to explore ways to maintain adequate space under and around seats, not only for service animals but the comfort and safety of passengers in general.

I'd recommend as few barriers to travel for passengers with service animals as possible. With that in mind, I strongly discourage the validation schemes in favor of the limitation to task-trained animals, tethering requirements such as those prescribed in the ADA, and observation of behavior as determining factors for boarding, and continuing in the cabin during flight. I stand with the American Veterinary Association (AVMA) in their position that veterinarians are not equipped to judge or predict an animals behavior during air travel and hence veterinary statements, if necessary, should not include any attestation to training. Regarding provision of veterinary forms, this requirement was removed for task-trained service animals currently by many airlines due to undo burdens, which should answer the questions posed about such burdens. I'd also like to each airlines to archive my files, so I do not have to submit them every time I travel.
docAbstract: Traveling by Air with Service Animals Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM)

text:
Please use KISS (Keep It Simple and Straightforward) principal when labeling bioengineered products providing consumers clear knowledge of what they are considering for purchase and consumption. KISS GMO on label, not the hidden alternative of a smiley face which would require a translator to comprehend.

Thank you for your consideration.

I believe service dogs for the blind , epilepsy monitoring dogs and other dogs that spend considerable hours, days and weeks being trained groomed to handle the unusual prior to being trained with their individual should be allowed to fly. Service horses are not bathroom trained and should not be allowed in public transportation.

There should be no other animals other than service dogs on flights. And those service dogs must have completed a tough and rigorous certification course set up by the DOT for behavior - crowds, tight spaces and other conditions found in airports, trains and terminals. Until there is a certification process for emotional support, psych support or other medical condition dogs that individuals need for any reason, then these dogs should either not be allowed or required to be muzzled and contained in carriers especially for flights. If large and unable to stay under the seat, they should have to have a ticket. I do not want to share my assigned seat space as it is small already.

I really do not want to fly next to a dog or any animal and especially an untrained one. The seats are too small, the floor space is non existent. It is impossible to not touch or accidentally invade another seat space for a second while adjusting clothing which could trigger aggressive behaviors. I do not want to worry about being bitten, attacked, scratched or arrive hair covered and smelly due to an animal on my flight or a previous one. Nor, do I want to listen to an animal whine, bark or scratch during my flight or in a confined area like a terminal.

I have restless leg syndrome and when it occurs, I need to move my legs nearly continuously, randomly and sometimes largely. I dont want to worry that it could be interpreted as aggressive or annoying by an animal causing them to react in an aggressive manner.

For all these reasons, I believe only service dogs that have been certified an accredited process should be allowed on public transportation.

text:
Dear Sir or Ma'am,

I am writing to ask that you please support the motion that there be clear labeling of GMO's on ALL food packaging. The USDA should know that clear product /clear package labeling is essential, and act accordingly.
Thank you.

This comment addresses the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) proposed rule titled National Bioengineered Food Disclosure Standard (NBFDS) as published in the May 4, 2018, Federal Register. The Notice proposes to add a Part 66 to Title 7 of the Code of Federal Regulations, to implement subtitles E (consisting of sections 291 through 294) and F [consisting of sections 295 and 296 of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 (AMA), as amended by Public Law 114-216 (July 29, 2016)].

Consistent with Law (Pub. L. 114-216) and precedent of Federal labeling, the final rule should put into action the following key provisions:
No USDA-NOP certified products will require disclosure as bioengineered;
USDA shall consider organic certification sufficient to make a claim regarding the absence of bioengineering in the food, such as not bioengineered, not genetically engineered, nonGMO, or another similar claim;
Recognize and allow common terms and shorthand that industry and consumers understand, such as genetic engineering, genetically modified, not GE, and non-GMO;
Adopt symbol disclosure options that 1) utilize acronyms that consumers are familiar with such as GE or GMO, and 2) are consistent with the non-bias stylistic tone of other AMS logos by not allowing emotion invoking (smiles and winking eye) symbols in the logo; and,
Adopt a threshold for inadvertent or technically unavoidable bioengineered DNA that is consistent with the level adopted by other major trading partners (no more than 0.9% of the specific ingredient).

Clarkson Grain Co., Inc. thanks USDA for the opportunity to provide comment on this important issue. We recognize the importance of this Rule in domestic commerce, and the international implications of the USDA Rule.

Respectfully submitted,
Kenneth A. Dallmier
President/Chief Operating Officer

Because of my personal experiences with my Guide Dog, I would strongly encourage licensing of service animals, including psychiatric service animals. I have been (illegally) questioned about my guide by a state employee in Illinois and was asked for a license (which doesn't exist). I would be happy to carry a license or have a special license (like a rabies tag) on my dogs collar. This would stop people from trying to pass of their pets as service animals because they could be asked to show this identification. Note that even a licensed service animal is no guarantee of behavior in any given situation so personnel need to be trained to determine what is acceptable behavior versus non-acceptable behavior, and they should be allowed to refuse any animal that poses a health or safety issue to others.

There should be no size limit for a service animal; if they're properly trained, any size will do.

Service animals should ALWAYS be tethered in some way to its' handler.

Health certificates should NOT be required for the service animal to travel. This causes undue burden to the handler in time for scheduling, cost and time to get a vet to perform the health check. This is also no guarantee that the animal remains healthy up to and including the flight(s) scheduled.
docAbstract: Traveling by Air with Service Animals Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM)

Your proposal seems to be just another attempt to change a name of something familiar to an unfamiliar name to at best confuse the consumer if not misleading the consumer.

GMO is a term we are familiar with and understand. The word bioengineered is a weasel-word that is designed to confuse and obfuscate the truth.

We need to know what is in our food using words and terms we are familiar with. What you are proposing is similar to changing the word liberal to progressive. Liberal was a lightning-rod term; so quit using it and use progressive instead. Doesn't fix anything but takes away some of the negative attitude.

Using bioengineered instead of GMO doesn't change anything - but will confuse people who won't know it means GMO. Change the name to protect the guilty.

Do not proceed with this proposal.

This is a comment about the proposed "BE" symbols. These symbols were apparently "designed to communicate the bioengineered status of a food in a way that would not disparage biotechnology or suggest BE food is more or less safe than non-BE food," however these symbols depicting smiling faces and the word BE are, in fact, biased. I additionally think that the abbreviation BE is misleading, and that the letters GMO should be used on the final label.

The purpose of a label is to inform the consumer, not to hide, trick, or mislead. By representing products with genetically modified ingredients with a smiling face and the word "BE", it is clear that the intent of the label is not to inform, but to generate a positive response based on a lack of understanding. These symbols are clearly in line with corporate interest, and were not designed with the intent of transparency or to help American consumers to make more informed purchasing choices.

ALL Americans have a right to know what theyre eating. Thats why I support clear, consumer-friendly GMO labels on ALL foods containing GMO ingredients.

The proposed rule allows companies to disclose GMOs solely through digital disclosures, while doing nothing to guarantee Americans without smartphones or cell service will have access to vital information about their food.

The USDA needs to ensure ALL Americans have access to GMO disclosures. Heres why:

- A Deloitte study found that nearly one-in-four Americans dont own a smartphone and that three-in-four dont know that you can scan QR codes to get production information. Most have never scanned a code to get food information, and 85 percent of Americans who have tried said they have struggled with mobile scanning apps. Compounding the fact that many Americans still dont have smartphones is the fact that more than 20 million American have lousy cell service. That means that it will take a long time for the GMO information to load if it loads at all.

- The proposed rule currently does not provide comparable options. The text message option included in the proposed rule should not be considered a comparable option because it is not clear that this option must be included in addition to the digital disclosure. Additionally, millions of Americans who live in rural areas may not have reliable cellphone service that would allow them to send or receive text messages.

- The law clearly directs the USDA secretary to provide additional and comparable options so that consumers who dont have smartphones or live in parts of the country without reliable cellular service can access the GMO disclosure, if the agency determines they will not have sufficient access to the GMO disclosure through electronic or digital methods.

- Comparable options need to be just as convenient as it is for someone to pull out a smartphone to scan a product. This could most easily be achieved by requiring stores to place scanners in every aisle of grocery stores, unless a retailer requires that manufacturers disclose the presence of GMOs on packages.

I urge you to create a clear, consumer-friendly GMO labeling standard that ensures ALL Americans have access to vital information about their food.

Thank you

Please note: for a information label for genetically modified food, be, for bioengineered, is misleading and confusing. It suggests a different meaning than gmo, genetically modified organism. Please be accurate and use "genetically modified" and/or "gmo" in creating a label. People are already so unaware of where their food comes from. At least be accurate for those who care to know..

Thank you,

Re: RIN No. 2105-AE63/DOT-OST-2018-0068.
For almost 90 years, guide dogs have been a vital tool for helping to secure independence and opportunity for tens of thousands of Americans who are blind and visually impaired, exemplifying the potential certain animals possess in aiding humans through extensive training and ongoing obedience.
Guide dog advocates have argued for years that there needs to be greater harmony between the ADA definition of service animals and other federal agency definitions protecting access in places of public access and travel, asserting that animals not trained for service in places of public accommodation pose a risk if not managed responsibly.
No regulation should create an undue burden for passengers relying upon well-trained service animals.
Verbal attestation and documentation alone will not stop the rampant fraud of false representation and presence of disobedient animals aboard aircraft; rather, there needs to be persistent training of personnel, public education and pressure on bad actors who provide false documentation.

Jennifer Devereaux

text:
To Whom It May Concern:
have a right to know what Im eating. Thats why I support clear, common-sense GMO labels.

The rule proposes using the term BE instead of GE or GMO, which will only confuse and mislead consumers. The USDA should use words consumers are already familiar with. Heres why:

- The terms bioengineered food or contains bioengineered food ingredients have never been used by a federal agency or the 64 other countries that require GMO labels.
- The USDA should consider the terms genetic engineering, genetic modification, and GMO as interchangeable with bioengineering for purposes of the disclosure standard and requirement because of their contemporaneous use in state and federal policy, as well as in international standards and guidelines developed by Codex Alimentarius.
- Prior to passage of Pub. L. 114-216, three states Connecticut, Maine and Vermont passed mandatory disclosure laws for GE foods and Alaska established a mandatory disclosure law for GE salmon. Each of these laws used the term genetic engineering to describe the technology, and the terms genetically engineered or genetically modified for the purposes of the disclosure requirement.
- In addition to state laws, federal policy has long used the terms genetic modification and genetic engineering to describe this process, as do USDAs own regulations of plants produced using biotechnology.
- The term bioengineering is most often related to the medical field. Websters Dictionary defines it as the biological or medical application of engineering principles (as the theory of control systems in models of the nervous system) or engineering equipment (as in the construction of artificial organs).

I urge you to create a clear, consumer-friendly GMO labeling standard that ensures all consumers will understand vital information about their food.

Thank you.
Wouldn't it be great if legislation followed common sense, so that labels said what they meant and meant what they said.

The point of labelling genetically modified foods is so that the public is aware when they are about to consume substances which have not been proved safe for human consumption. Using a smiley face and the letters BE as a warning is the height of hypocrisy as well as craven pandering to the bioengineering industry.

We deserve better.

We, the American people,  have had enough of being poisoned by the food we eat. Why do you think the cancer rate so  outrageous? This has got to stop before  our next generations suffer the consequences. The rate of our children getting cancer and other diseases has gone up exponentially. If you dont want this to happen to your children and grandchildren I suggest you do something to protect our food. Chemical company should be held accountable for poisoning  people and should not get away with their behavior anymore. We need a strong advocate to protect our food sources.  Companies are much too greedy and only look at the bottom line: money! Once upon a time people trusted in the FDA. Now we have to beg just for food without chemicals?

Re: docket identification (ID) number CEQ-2018-0001

Dear Counsel on Environmental Quality,

You are entrusted with ensuring full and fair implementation of the National Environmental Policy Act.

In order to ensure a full and fair opportunity to answer the questions put forth in the June 20, 2018 public notice, I urge you to extend the comment period an additional 90 days. These are complicated questions and vitally important issues. Thirty days is not enough time to provide a full and fair opportunity for the public to be heard - especially given your obvious intent to seek to rollback the law and the public's future opportunity to be heard pursuant to NEPA.

In addition, I want to be on record to make clear, I oppose any efforts to weaken this iconic and important law. NEPA ensures that the voices of all people are heard in the federal decisionmaking process when our health, our environment, our communities and economies could be harmed. And it ensures that government agencies, and the public, have the best opportunity for full information on impacts and alternatives before decisions that will have irreparable environmental, economic, and public health impacts are allowed to advance. Taking any steps that
> weaken the opportunity for public input,
> undermine full and forthright consideration of alternatives to decisionmaking,
> weaken the mandate to consider all impacts of proposed actions, including consideration of the cumulative effect of proposed actions,
> remove or weaken the prohibition against the use of segmentation by agencies or applicants in order to evade full impact review,
> remove the mandate that agencies consider the climate changing impacts of projects or proposals under review,
> or in anyway rollback the existing elements of the law as it currently stands
would be a violation of your duty to enforce the law and defend the rights of all people to be fully and fairly protected and heard.

I oppose your efforts to revise NEPA - the law is strong and effective as it now stands.
I urge you to expand the public comment period an additional 90 days.

Respectfully,

Genetically Modified Organisms are known by the public by that very name.

The only reason to suggest creating a new name for something that is already well known is to obfuscate (hide) from the public the truth about what is being sold.

Putting the new name's initials in a smiley face is further indication that the Agency is attempting to put a positive spin on something that society looks at with distrust.

Leaving aside any judgment as to the relative value of GMOs in general, the Agency should not be attempting to influence public opinion, nor hide a food's source, but should instead be providing the public with terminology that everyone is familiar with, in a neutral fashion. This will facilitate the public's process of choosing what they prefer to consume.

I strongly oppose the proposed attempts to relabel GMOs as "BE", and also oppose the use of a smiley face to put a positive spin on these items.

Please respect the wishes of those of us (most of us) who do not want genetically engineered food for ourselves, our loved ones or our pets. Passing off "bio-engineered" "BE" food via deceptive wording and marketing is dishonest and lacking in integrity.
I go out of my way to avoid GMO foods and so do a great many other citizens. Please allow us this right --to clearly know what we are getting--when we shop for food.
I support the IACP's position and statements on this regulation
docAbstract: Traveling by Air with Service Animals Advance Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (ANPRM)

1) THERE SHOULD BE PENALTIES FOR NON-COMPLIANCE AND THEY SHOULD BE STEEP. THERE ARE CURRENTLY NO PENALTIES WHATSOEVER FOR COMPANIES THAT DON'T LABEL SOMETHING THAT IS GMO!!!

2) Include ALL foods created with ALL types of genetic engineering including new gene-editing techniques such as CRISPR and SynBio, and any methods developed in the future. NO LOOPHOLES AND EXEMPTIONS for these technologies.

3) NO EXEMPTIONS for highly processed foods, such as cooking oils, where GMO DNA cannot be detected using current testing methods. Any products sourced from GMO crops must be labeled as GMO.

4) Labeling must use the common, well-established labeling term "GMO" or GE (genetically engineered). Use of the proposed and little-known term "bioengineered," or still worse the entirely unfamiliar acronym "BE," to denote GMO content, would only mislead and confuse consumers.

5) Require neutral symbols. No smiley or sunshine faces. These biased symbols are pro-biotech propaganda.

6) Contamination tolerance levels should be identical to the EU standard of 0.9%.

7) Reject discriminatory QR codes, text message options and other options that are not simple text on the food package.

8) Demand disclosure now - not in 2022!

Anti-GMO and GMO warnings are an insult to Actual Science, and a menace to public health. There is no risk involved in consuming GMO products. NONE. That is the Science and any suggestion to the contrary, or any complicity in a vicious false myth is anti-Science, and supportive of the current fascist regime and it's essential and intentional muddling of truth itself. Shame on this idea. Shame.

Science and only is the way out of this mess. For the survival of the species itself, stop promoting lies. GMOs are NO DANGER. NONE. Get it? This is Science: YOU DON'T GET TO CHOOSE WHAT IS THE TRUTH.

Only Certified Service Dogs should be allowed on planes...no matter what the breed of that dog. I, personally, have Therapy Dogs who help support people in need during disasters etc BUT they are not Certified Service Dogs and should not be allowed on a plane with me. There is a huge difference between a Certified Service Dog and a Registered Therapy Dog (not to mention the pet companions whos owner simply slaps a vest on their dog and calls is a service dog)!

text: I believe that  NOSSCR has made several good points and raised multiple valid concerns in their comments. The mere use of hand held assistive devices that require both hands are not the only way to medically measure a disabling level of dysfunction when ambulating. For example, if an individual braces themselves on the walls of a hallway to walk they may have no use of their hands for carrying when they walk but would be precluded from being found medically disabled. The requirement for imaging to correspond to compromise of a nerve root can also be unnecessarily disqualifying. As noted by NOSSCR some claimant's lack the means or a provider willing to obtain advanced imaging that can show more detailed information to confirm compromise. Additionally, such imaging is not always accurate. Poor quality or poor interpretation can deny an individual rights to benefits even though they may have the other criteria. I have seen situations where an MRI does not identify compromise on imaging, but a surgeon has been willing to operate on clinical examination findings and has had direct visualization of compromise upon surgery.
docAbstract:
This notice of proposed rulemaking (NPRM) is divided into several parts. First, we provide the supplementary information, which is often referred to as the preamble. In the preamble, we explain why we propose to revise the listings for the musculoskeletal body system and how we developed the proposed rules. We also offer a narrative of the changes we are proposing. The preamble tells the story behind the proposed rule changes, but if we decide to proceed with a final rule, the preamble will not become part of the Code of Federal Regulations.


 
The next section is the proposed revisions to the listing of impairments, located in Appendix 1 to Subpart P of 20 CFR part 404. For each body system affected by these proposed rules (e.g., 1.00 Musculoskeletal Disorders), we first provide proposed changes to the introductory text (e.g., 1.00A, B, C, etc.). If we decide to proceed with a final rule, the introductory text will become part of the Code of Federal Regulations. The introductory text details which disorders we evaluate and what evidence we need to conduct this evaluation. It also defines certain terms, and provides valuable background information. Individuals often refer to the introductory text for additional details related to a specific listing under which a medically determinable impairment (MDI) is being evaluated. After the introductory text, we provide specific listing text and criteria (e.g., 1.15 and 1.16). The listings themselves provide specific criteria that an MDI must meet (or medically equal) in order for an individual to be found disabled under the listings.

text: This is misleading and ineffective . NO GOOD

Dear Sirs, now that the DARK act has been passed, taking away states' rights in labeling, it is doubly important that a fair federal rule be put in place for GMO foods. The proposed rule is all for giant agribiz benefit, and should be altered.
The rule proposes that scanning QR squares will be the way to find out information. Scanning these speckled black squares with your smart phone will lead to additional product information. Of course this requires an internet connection and a smart phone or other device. It is estimated that 130 million Americans lack the resources to do this. Thus it is discriminatory. QR codes allow companies to camouflage their GMO ingredient information. This is not acceptable.
Also, the USDA has released some preliminary logos for potential use with GMO products. The smiley face, feel-good images suggested provide no value other than encouraging your acceptance of the product. The use of the lettering, BE, is disingenuous. It is supposed to stand for bioengineered, a term most consumers are not familiar with (most are familiar with GE/genetic engineering or GMO/genetically modified organism). This logo is unacceptable. To make it even more confusing, the image closely resembles logos used in the European Union to signify organic products. How insulting is that? This logo is intentionally misleading and should be dumped.
The USDA remains undecided on whether processed foods made with GMO corn, soy, sugar beets, and canola must display GMO product information. Consumers have the right to know this information, and the USDA must require full disclosure of GMO ingredients in food products.
Please do the right thing and ignore the lobbying of Big Ag. Allow consumers the information they deserve.
Thank you, Nancy McMillan

American Democracy MUST include right to know and transparency in food disclosures for ALL foods, including bioengineered foods, GMOs, organic standards et al.

Every taxpaying citizen has the right to review this information printed on each product in order to make educated decisions on what WE decide to consume for ourselves and our families.

You need to protect ALL Americans rights concerning this matter.

Genetically Modified Organisms are making people sick! This is well documented, and more and more people are becoming aware of that fact.

Changing terminology and using cutesy cartoonish icons sends the wrong message. It also dupes those who are less informed into thinking GMOs are actually safe to eat.

Show the public that at least one governmental agency is trying to carry out the duties for which it was created - protect the public from harmful ingredients. If you can't stop them from putting them into products, make sure that the public is being made aware of what is in them by ensuring that appropriate and clearly stated/understood labeling is being used. People are looking at labels. They are looking for signs that the consumables they buy are actually safe to consume.

Consumers are trying to apply economic pressure to companies to use appropriate labels, but that means nothing if the regulations for those labels allows for deceptive use or deceptive labeling itself! You must show the public that you are working in their interests and not that of the corporations.
I support the SBTC ELD exemption application

To Whom It May Concern:

The FDA should not consider imposing this possible rule as it is unreasonable and would unfairly target adult tobacco consumers by essentially banning the legal products they prefer without having widespread access to and information about alternative, less harmful tobacco products.

A mandate that cigarettes have nearly 98 percent less nicotine than current levels would be a de facto ban on all cigarettes currently on the market. By effectively banning these products---without first creating a market for less harmful alternative tobacco products---the FDA's possible rule is simply unfair and unreasonable.

Beyond just adult smokers, this possible rule would hurt our economy. A de facto ban on cigarettes would threaten American tobacco growers and manufacturing. Given that the vast majority of cigarettes sold in the United States are manufactured domestically from American-grown tobacco, such an severe regulatory mandate would have a serious negative impact on U.S. manufacturing, agriculture, and jobs.

The FDA should focus its resources on a comprehensive plan that reduces harm and risk for adult tobacco consumers through proven strategies to prevent initiation, encourage cessation, and by the development of reduced risk alternatives to cigarettes that adult smokers like. Please reconsider this drastic regulatory change.

To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing today to submit my comment on the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA's) possible new rule concerning the nicotine levels in cigarettes. By mandating that the levels of nicotine be reduced nearly 98 percent, this possible rule would essentially ban all cigarettes on the market today. This possible rule is unfair to adult smokers, and may not even be achievable. The FDA should not move forward without considering the impact it would have on adult smokers as well as our larger economy.

Once again, the government is trying to solve a problem by restricting choice rather than by giving adults more alternatives. Rather than reduce choice for adult smokers, the FDA should focus on giving adult smokers more options and access to a wider choice of less harmful tobacco products, and truthful, accurate information about the benefits of switching to them. Instead, this de facto ban would simply target adult smokers for purchasing the legal products they prefer.

FDA should focus resources on a comprehensive plan to reduce harm through proven strategies to prevent initiation, encourage cessation and by fostering the development of reduced risk alternatives to cigarettes that are satisfying to adult smokers.

Please do not consider such a severe and unfair proposal.

Please reconsider this drastic regulatory change.

text:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am opposed to the possible new nicotine rule the FDA is currently considering in the form it is presented. If enacted, it would be unfair to adult smokers, threaten our economy, and may not even be technically achievable. Please oppose this effort.

Before implementing any nicotine standard the FDA should ensure that adult smokers have access to a much greater variety of less harmful alternatives, and to information about the benefits of switching to them. FDA should focus resources on a comprehensive plan to reduce harm through proven strategies to prevent initiation, encourage cessation and by fostering the development of reduced risk alternatives to cigarettes that are satisfying to adult smokers.

If a rule such as the one being considered were enacted, it would basically remove all cigarettes and cigars currently on the market today. This is essentially a de facto ban on the products many adult tobacco consumers prefer as there are currently no combustible tobacco products on the market today that meet the unreasonable restriction the FDA is considering.

Everyone can support reasonable regulations, but this goes too far. Not only would this possible rule target adult tobacco consumers and limit their choices and the options available to them, but it could seriously hurt U.S. tobacco growers and manufacturing. The overwhelming majority of cigarettes sold in the United States are manufactured right here by American manufacturers using tobacco grown here. A de facto ban on cigarettes would have a devastating impact on the manufacturing and agricultural sectors, as well as the jobs they support.

This possible rule is unfair and would have far too many unintended, negative consequence. Please keep my views in mind and do not advance such a severe regulatory mandate.

To whom it May Concern,

Recent polls show that a whopping 71 percent of Alaskan voters oppose allowing hunters to use artificial light to attract hibernating
bears and their cubs out of their dens to kill them. Sixty-nine percent oppose hunting black bears with packs of hounds, and
75 percent oppose hunting swimming caribou with the aid of motorboats. Sixty percent of Alaskan voters oppose the baiting of
bears with pet food, grease, rotting game or fish or other high-calorie foods, and 57 percent oppose killing whole packs of wolves
and coyotes when they are raising their pups in their dens.

Most Alaskans do not want hunters, backed by the deep pockets of trophy-hunting groups like Safari Club International and
Alaska Outdoor Council, treating their state as a shopping mall for bearskin rugs and wolf heads to adorn their walls.

Please do NOT allow the above cruel and unfair hunting practices to be put in place. It is a DISGRACE that anyone would even
consider allowing this to happen.

Thank you.

I am asking that my National Park Service continue to protect the wildlife in Alaska from inhumane hunting methods. I understand that the majority of Alaskan residents oppose the use of such unsportsmanlike and cruel behavior such as: using artificial light to attract hibernating bears and cubs out of their dens in order to kill them, hunting swimming caribou from motorboats, and baiting bears with rich food in order to shoot them. Also a recent poll showed that most Alaskans are strongly opposed to trophy hunting on state lands. I have never had the pleasure of being in Alaska, but support the majority of Americans there who want to preserve and conserve the wildlife that brings $2 billion dollars yearly into their economy by attracting tourists who want to see animals in their natural habitat, without shooting these animals.

It is horrible to think that the National Park Service, an organization that I assume is filled with environmentalists and people who take pride in the beauty of this country, is being pressured to rollback protections for the wildlife in our public lands. Please resist, as a nation we need to know that there are still wild places that support a diverse ecological system, and that the animals on our public lands will not be sacrificed or sold to the highest bidder who only appreciate the bragging rights that come with killing a wild animal. Or ten.

Thank you for reaching out for comments from concerned citizens. Please continue to protect the animals on our public lands, as well as the public lands that are being threatened by development under our current administration.

My family and I are sincerely asking that Department of Interior abandon the proposed rule (RIN 1024-AE38).
The proposed rule seeks to repeal a carefully considered and crafted 2015 rule that prohibited overly aggressive predator control practices on National Preserves in Alaska. The 2015 rule was supported by scientists and thousands of Americans who commented in support of protecting predators from these unsportsmanlike and cruel killing practices.
The 2015 rule banned cruel, unethical and outdated practices such as killing mother bears and cubs at their den sites; baiting brown and black bears with pastries or other human foods; killing wolves and coyotes with pups during their denning season; shooting caribou from boats or shore as they cross lakes or rivers; and using dogs to hunt bears.
These aforementioned practices are not permitted elsewhere in National Parks or Preserves.
Importantly, these practices are not in keeping with the spirit or the language of the National Park Services directive to "provide for the maintenance of sound populations of, and habitat for, wildlife species of inestimable value to the citizens of Alaska and the Nation." We care deeply about good sportsmanship and good wildlife stewardship and the 2015 rule aligns with these American values. The proposed rule very much does not!
Finally, the proposed rule would overturn an existing 2015 NPS rule that is consistent with federal law and outlaws overly aggressive predator control practices on these preserves in Alaska.
Thank you for your careful attention to our comments.

Ryan Zinke,

I am writing to encourage the Department of Interior to abandon the proposed rule (RIN 1024-AE38).

It seeks to repeal 2015 rule prohibiting overly aggressive management of predators on national preserves in Alaska. Included in the rightly-banned practices are the killing mother bears and cubs at den sites, baiting brown and black bears with pastries or other foods, killing wolves and coyotes with pups during their denning season, killing caribou from a boat, and using dogs to hunt bears.

David Meade
dvdmd7@gmail.com

Im writing today to demand that the Department of Interior abandon the proposed rule (RIN 1024-AE38).

I urge the Department of Interior to drop the proposed rule RIN 1024-AE38, which aims to repeal and replace a common-sense rule from 2015 that banned excessively aggressive predator control practices on National Preserves in Alaska.

In fact, that 2015 rule specifically prohibited barbaric and unethical methods such as shooting caribou from boats or shore as they cross rivers or lakes; using dogs to hunt bears; killing coyotes and wolves with pups during their dunning season; baiting brown bears with human foods, including pastries; and killing mother bears and cubs at their denning sites.

Nowhere else in National Parks and Preserves are such practices allowed, as they are definitely not furthering the spirit or wording of the National Park Service's directive to "provide for the maintenance of sound populations of, and habitat for, wildlife species of inestimable value to the citizens of Alaska and the Nation."

The 2015 NPS rule which outlaws unreasonably aggressive predator control practices, such as those enumerated above and any similar measures, on National Preserves in Alaska, and which is consistent with federal law, should NOT be jettisoned and replaced by the proposed rule RIN 1024-AE38, especially since that 2015 rule was supported by thousands of Americans, as well as scientists, who sent comments in its favor to ensure the protection of predators from these cruel killing practices.

I demand that the 2015 rule remain in place, and that the proposed rule RIN 1024-AE38 be rejected and abandoned.

The Final Rule established in October of 2015 should stand and any proposed changes discarded. Hunters and trappers have plenty of opportunity to kill animals without resorting to inhumane, unsportsmanlike practices such as those allowed under the proposed changes.

Science supports the October 2015 Final Rule; large predators are an essential part of the Alaskan ecosystem and allowing them to be killed in large numbers upsets the balance of nature. Plus, polls consistently show that a majority of Americans do not support practices such as those proposed, and visitors to our public lands want to see our iconic species in the wild.

Please support science and the will of the American people and do not make any changes to the Oct. 2015 Final Rule.

Please oppose the new rule that would revoke federal regulations currently protecting animals from barbaric hunting practices in federally owned wildlife refuges in Alaska. I don't want to see the National Park Service allow hunting and trapping in the National Preserves of Alaska for the following reasons:
It's cruel to allow methods such as the use of artificial light to attract bears and their cubs out of their dens to be killed or to bait
them with food.
It's cruel to use bait to attract bears and to use dogs to hunt bears.
Most of those Alaskans that were polled by the Remington Research Group pertaining to this issue of hunting hibernating
bears and the killing of whole packs of wolves and coyotes in their dens were opposed to this cruelty.
Most of Alaskan voters don't want trophy hunters and trappers killing wildlife on state lands.

Predator control, including trophy hunting and culling of native carnivores, has been shown to not work as has been found
in a recent new study that was reported in the Scientific American June 9th, 2018 issue, "Does Killing Sharks, Wolves and Other Top Predators
Solve Our Conflicts with Them?"
In this study, it is shown that because predators are essential to the ecosystem since they regulate prey
populations, without them the ecosystems become unbalanced and other smaller animals that were prey before, become larger
in numbers which can become threatening to other species.
In 141 studies of predator removal, success of creating a balance was rarely achieved, according to the article in Scientific
American as referenced above. What was found instead was that new predators moved in to the area where the former
predators had been removed from and recolonized the area, increasing the numbers of the new predator over the one that
was removed.

Also, there are ways to deal with the human conflict issue - electric fencing, bear-proof garbage cans, not leaving food out to attract bears,
and "re-wilding" an ecosystem, or bringing in more animals that are natural prey for carnivores, which reduces their interest in other animals.
Also, It's really the responsibility of people who may be living close to bear habitats to assume responsibility for bear proofing the areas
where they live.

Finally, most Alaskans don't want hunters, backed by trophy hunting groups like Safari Club, to massacre the wild animals just
so they can have something hanging on their walls. Most people would like to be able to see these majestic animals in the wild one
day and in Alaska, wildlife watching tourism brings in two billion dollars every year to their economy.

Please don't allow this cruel form of hunting that is being proposed. Please help preserve the animals for future generations.
Do the right thing for the animals! Thank you.

Im writing today to demand that the Department of Interior abandon the proposed rule (RIN 1024-AE38).
The proposed rule seeks to repeal a common-sense 2015 rule that prohibited overly aggressive predator control practices on National Preserves in Alaska.
The 2015 rule banned unethical and barbaric practices such as killing mother bears and cubs at their den sites; baiting brown and black bears with pastries or other human foods; killing wolves and coyotes with pups during their denning season; shooting caribou from boats or shore as they cross lakes or rivers; and using dogs to hunt bears.
These practices are not permitted elsewhere in National Parks or Preserves and are not in keeping with the spirit or the language of the National Park Services directive to "provide for the maintenance of sound populations of, and habitat for, wildlife species of inestimable value to the citizens of Alaska and the Nation."
This proposed rule would overturn an existing 2015 NPS rule that is consistent with federal law and outlaws overly aggressive predator control practices on these preserves in Alaska. This 2015 rule was supported by scientists and thousands of Americans who commented in support of protecting predators from these cruel killing practices.

Im opposed to the National Park Services proposed rule to repeal the 2015 regulatory provisions that prohibit killing black bears and their cubs with artificial light at den sites, using bait to attract brown bears for an easy shot, killing wolf and coyote mothers and pups in their dens, using dogs to hunt black bears, and killing defenseless swimming caribou.
The National Park Service should not reverse its original rule, which was carefully deliberated, based on the best available science, and subject to extensive public input.
As an American, I appreciate our native carnivores and believe that they should be treated humanely and with an appreciation for the critical role they play in maintaining a healthy ecosystem.
The National Park Service is directly contravening its own findings that the described methods of hunting and trapping frequently allowed by the Alaska Board of Game to increase opportunities to harvest predators are not consistent with the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act.
The 2015 protections currently in place only restrict sport hunting in national preserves, which constitute less than six percent of the area in Alaska open to hunting. These limitations are sufficient and reasonable.
The Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act and other federal laws mandate that the National Park Service preserve national lands, including national preserves, for the benefit of present and future generations.
The proposed rule will increase public safety concerns resulting from baiting of bears. This practice was originally prohibited by the NPS to help protect the public from food-conditioned bears, which are more likely to cause human injury.

docAbstract: The Department of Justice anticipates issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that would interpret the statutory definition of “machinegun” in the National Firearms Act of 1934 and Gun Control Act of 1968 to clarify whether certain devices, commonly known as “bump fire” stocks, fall within that definition. Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

text:
"...clarify that "bump fire" stocks, slide-fire devices, and devices with certain similar characteristics (bump-stock-type devices) are "machineguns" as defined by the National Firearms Act of 1934 (NFA) and the Gun Control Act of 1968 (GCA), because such devices allow a shooter of a semiautomatic firearm to initiate a continuous firing cycle with a SINGLE PULL OF THE TRIGGER."

This statement is patently false. A semi-automatic weapon BY DEFINITION can only discharge a single round per pull of the trigger. Since these devices do NOT alter the firing or cycling mechanisms of the semi-automatic weapon, they are still only discharging a single round per pull of the trigger.

If one were to wrap a zip-tie around the trigger to keep it depressed it would still only fire ONE round during the initial depress, regardless of the use of any of these "bump stock" devices -- meaning the the definition of a semi-automatic weapon still applies and it does not (and cannot) fire more than one round per pull of the trigger.

docAbstract: The Department of Justice anticipates issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that would interpret the statutory definition of “machinegun” in the National Firearms Act of 1934 and Gun Control Act of 1968 to clarify whether certain devices, commonly known as “bump fire” stocks, fall within that definition. Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

text:
ATF should act quickly to make this proposed rule final making clear that bump stocks are illegal because they enable shooters to transform their guns into automatic weapons. These devices have an especially deadly effect, and this rule would have an immeasurable public safety benefit.

Until ATF acts, bump stocks and other so-called "conversion devices" exploit a gap in federal law. As a result, they are inexpensive, easily attainable, and a grave public danger.

Finalizing ATF's rule is a major step, but it does not solve the entire conversion devices problem. Even with this final rule, we still need Congress to pass a law that makes all devices illegal if they enable shooters to mimic automatic gunfire.

Machine guns have been illegal to manufacture for over 30 years and any owner has gone through a special background check process and registered the machine gun with ATF. But conversion devices like bump stocks exploit the vague definition of "machine gun" in our federal law, and are designed specifically to get around the strong laws designed to keep fully automatic firearms out of civilian hands.

There is an immeasurable benefit to the public safety, including in my community, in making clear that bump stocks are illegal. Indeed, ATF's proposed rule is a regulation that enforces machine gun laws that date back many decades and it will have the same dramatic benefit originally intended by those foundational laws. That benefit is easy to see without bump stocks, the Las Vegas shooter would have been unable to shoot and kill 58 people and injure hundreds more in the space of only 10 minutes.

text: I work in the auto manufacturing sector and disagree with a decision to add a tariff on goods imported to produce our parts or vehicles. I feel that if a tax is added to these goods this will hurt our company and our community. Our company has many Americans employed, and I think that additional tariff's will negatively affect our jobs.

Tariffs are a direct tax on American companies and consumers.

Imports of autos and auto parts do not threaten American security. Imposing a 25% tariff on these products risks economic harm and the threat of retaliatory tariffs.

The specialty and performance parts industry is made up primarily of small businesses that have no impact on domestic industrial capacity and national security.

Tariffs would endanger the automotive hobby, which is enjoyed by millions of Americans.

Millions of American workers are employed within the industry segment that imports automobiles and auto parts.

Millions of American workers are also employed domestically in producing automobiles and auto parts that are exported to the global marketplace. Tariffs would endanger those manufacturing jobs.

Millions of American workers are also employed domestically in producing automobiles and auto parts that are exported to the global marketplace. Tariffs would endanger those manufacturing jobs.

To Whom It May Concern,

This tariff will cause catastrophic damage to the South Eastern Automotive Industry.
By implementing this tax, you will be jeopardizing tens of thousands of American jobs and the economic stability of our region.
This would do more harm to National Security and overall stability of our National Economy.
Since the majority of ALL automakers rely on foreign trade for sub components, this bill would harm every auto parts manufacturer and assembly facility whether it's Head Quarter is based in the United States or in a foreign country.
Several automobile manufacturers are dealing with inventory and market issues as it is and we are afraid something like this could be the " Straw that broke the camels back"
We all know that higher taxes cause higher prices, higher prices cause a difficulty of purchase, and less purchases results in less jobs needed. People without a job cannot purchase anything and then other sectors of the economy start dramatically dropping as well.
So we strongly ask you to reconsider this under the current terms of Section 232.

I also ask that you exclude classic and collector cars.  Most of the classic and collector car owners are not wealthy and a 25% tax would be devastating to the classic and collector community, and would provide little to no benefit to achieving the Presidents goals, which I do indeed support.
This is mindless and a terrible proposal. Not only will it hurt our economy but it will stunt American growth and innovation.

On the night of October 1, 2017, a gunman opened fire from a hotel room on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel into the 22,000 person crowd at the Route 91 Harvest country music festival in Las Vegas, Nevada, killing 58 people and injuring more than 500. The gunman fired more than 1,100 rounds of ammunition in 11 minutes, using semi-automatic rifles modified with dangerous firearm accessories designed to dramatically accelerate the rate of gunfire, commonly known as bump fire stocks.

These devices are intended to circumvent the restrictions on possession of fully automatic firearms in the Gun Control Act of 1968 and the National Firearms Act of 1934 by allowing an individual to modify a semiautomatic rifle in such a manner that it operates with a similar rate of fire as a fully automatic rifle, posing a substantial risk to public safety.

In the absence of immediate action by Congress, I urge ATF to finalize its proposed rule clarifying that bump fire stocks, along with other conversion devices that enable semiautomatic weapons to mimic automatic fire, qualify as machine guns under the National Firearms Act. And then Congress must act as wellto ensure that manufacturers cannot continue to endanger public safety by designing devices that imitate machine guns and subvert the law.

The continued presence of these dangerous devices puts all of our communities at risk, and both Congress and ATF must take action quickly to address this threat.

Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

These devices are intended to circumvent the restrictions on possession of fully automatic firearms in the Gun Control Act of 1968 and the National Firearms Act of 1934 by allowing an individual to modify a semiautomatic rifle in such a manner that it operates with a similar rate of fire as a fully automatic rifle, posing a substantial risk to public safety.

In the absence of immediate action by Congress, I urge ATF to finalize its proposed rule clarifying that bump fire stocks, along with other conversion devices that enable semiautomatic weapons to mimic automatic fire, qualify as machine guns under the National Firearms Act. And then Congress must act as wellto ensure that manufacturers cannot continue to endanger public safety by designing devices that imitate machine guns and subvert the law.

The continued presence of these dangerous devices puts all of our communities at risk, and both Congress and ATF must take action quickly to address this threat.
docAbstract: The Department of Justice anticipates issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that would interpret the statutory definition of “machinegun” in the National Firearms Act of 1934 and Gun Control Act of 1968 to clarify whether certain devices, commonly known as “bump fire” stocks, fall within that definition. Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

Re: docket identification (ID) number CEQ-2018-0001

Dear Counsel on Environmental Quality,

You are entrusted with ensuring full and fair implementation of the National Environmental Policy Act.

In order to ensure a full and fair opportunity to answer the questions put forth in the June 20, 2018 public notice, I urge you to extend the comment period an additional 90 days. These are complicated questions and vitally important issues. Thirty days is not enough time to provide a full and fair opportunity for the public to be heard - especially given your obvious intent to seek to rollback the law and the public's future opportunity to be heard pursuant to NEPA.

In addition, I want to be on record to make clear, I oppose any efforts to weaken this iconic and important law. NEPA ensures that the voices of all people are heard in the federal decisionmaking process when our health, our environment, our communities and economies could be harmed. And it ensures that government agencies, and the public, have the best opportunity for full information on impacts and alternatives before decisions that will have irreparable environmental, economic, and public health impacts are allowed to advance. Taking any steps that
> weaken the opportunity for public input,
> undermine full and forthright consideration of alternatives to decisionmaking,
> weaken the mandate to consider all impacts of proposed actions, including consideration of the cumulative effect of proposed actions,
> remove or weaken the prohibition against the use of segmentation by agencies or applicants in order to evade full impact review,
> remove the mandate that agencies consider the climate changing impacts of projects or proposals under review,
> or in anyway rollback the existing elements of the law as it currently stands
would be a violation of your duty to enforce the law and defend the rights of all people to be fully and fairly protected and heard.

I oppose your efforts to revise NEPA - the law is strong and effective as it now stands.
I urge you to expand the public comment period an additional 90 days.

Respectfully,
I support the ELD exemption SBITC is presenting

text: Catch Lionfish any way you can.
docAbstract: The National Marine Fisheries Service has received an application for an EFP from the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC).  If granted, the EFP would allow the deployment of modified wire spiny lobster traps in the federal waters of the South Atlantic.  The proposed research would examine the efficiency and efficacy of modified trap designs for capturing lionfish, with the goal of identifying the best modification to maximize lionfish catch and reduce bycatch.  The EFP would exempt these research activities from federal regulations at 50 CFR 622.9(c) (prohibited gear and methods-general, fish traps).

We need clear, on-package labels for GMOs, not misleading smiley faces or confusing QR codes.  Label GMO foods as GMO, effective immediately.

Please make it mandatory for ALL GM foods, including foods that have been fed with GM foods to be labeled. In addition ALL bioengenerd foods need to be labeled in a manner that it does not appear friendly thus leading the public that it is a safe product to consume. Genetically engineered foods have been proven to produce tumors along with other life threatening illnesses and have been banned in several countries. However if people choose to consume such foods that is their choice. But give the public a fair warning so they can then make an educated decision. Families that are health conscious and want their loved ones to consume safe products have a right to know what they are buying and have it be presented in such a way it is easy to recognize. The proposed ' Happy looking' " BE" on foods is misleading and although not criminal in a legal sense it is criminal ethically to unsuspecting consumers.

Thank you for your time.
Tracey Stoff

I very strongly urge you to REQUIRE that clearly identifiable information (NOT just a silly unclear logo OR a scan area that must be read by a cell phone or similar device) be incorporated on packaging of ALL future food items which contain genetically-modified ingredients. We DESERVE & should have the RIGHT to KNOW what is & is not in the foods we eat & share with our loved ones! Not everyone has access to technology that would be required to read the scan-able portion of packaging, AND we should be able to easily identify what is in the package we're considering purchasing, with very CLEAR, LEGIBLE labeling of the same.

The companies which so readily promote their GMOs, and claim that there is no downside to the health of humans & our environment due to use or consumption of their products, should therefore, NOT have any problem with having their products listed as containing GMOs, if that is the case. So, let the consumer be allowed to make an INFORMED decision in what they buy & eat. We demand that should have that RIGHT in this country!!

Why is it that the 'developed' country of the United States, a forward-thinking leader in the world, is one of only a few countries which does NOT yet REQUIRE GMO labeling on food items????? We MUST NOW join the other countries in DEMANDING clear labeling of foods which contains GMOs

PLEASE listen to & help concerned consumers over the reckless, greedy companies who continue to push their GMO foods, without regard or respect for consumers. The time is NOW to REQUIRE CLEAR, LEGIBLE labeling of ALL foods, indicating if they contain GMO ingredients!!!

Thank you for your time on this vital issue.
As a concerned citizen who cares about the kind of food I eat, I want CLEAR LABELING of ALL GMOs on ALL FOOD PACKAGING.

I Want my food labeled GMO!!!!

1) Include ALL foods created with ALL types of genetic engineering including new gene-editing techniques such as CRISPR and SynBio, and any methods developed in the future. NO LOOPHOLES AND EXEMPTIONS for these technologies.

2) NO EXEMPTIONS for highly processed foods, such as cooking oils, where GMO DNA cannot be detected using current testing methods. Any products sourced from GMO crops must be labeled as GMO.

3) Labeling must use the common, well-established labeling term "GMO" or GE (genetically engineered). Use of the proposed and little-known term "bioengineered," or still worse the entirely unfamiliar acronym "BE," to denote GMO content, would only mislead and confuse consumers.

4) Require neutral symbols. No smiley or sunshine faces. These biased symbols are pro-biotech propaganda.

5) Contamination tolerance levels should be identical to the EU standard of 0.9%.

6) Reject discriminatory QR codes, text message options and other options that are not simple text on the food package.

7) Demand disclosure now - not in 2022!

8) There should be penalties for non-compliance and they should be steep. There are currently no penalties whatsoever for companies that don't label something that's GMO.

I object to this deceptive and uninformative logo that is supposed to give consumers access to GMO content for foods. In addition it eliminates those who do not have the necessary app on their phone, which is 130 million in the US, a number in which I am included. Even for those who do have the necessary app and technical skill to use it, it is cumbersome and time consuming for anyone who wants to access it as they are attempting to complete a shopping trip in the most efficient manner. Imagine also having to care for a child or two as you are shopping and having to stop to get this information. It seems to me that this system is designed to discourage folks from accessing the information about GMO's from the food packaging and is just catering to corporate interests, not the needs of the public who desire this information. Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Symbol 2A that is my choice. I support labeling genetically engineered food and food products with symbol 2A and the word Bioengineered directly below symbol 2A. Consumers deserve transparency, and studies have shown that consumers trust genetically modified foods more when they are given the chance to see which foods are modified (see Mandatory labels can improve attitudes toward genetically engineered food by Jane Kolodinsky and Jayson L. Lusk in ScienceAdvances). Label 2A provides a clear, concise, and ubiquitous symbol that represents genetic engineering technology.

Food labels must be clear or they are ineffective. Bioengineered written text below symbol 2A is the clearest way to label bioengineered food products. This label is clear because it explains the BE in the logo and informs consumers that the label specifically refers to bioengineering in the context of agriculture. Scientists around the world have reached a consensus that genetically modified (GM) crops are just as safe as crops produced through conventional plant breeding. Label 2A reflects this by providing a nonthreatening symbol that requires little active effort to understand and does not diminish the importance of the science behind genetic engineering by being cutesy like the sun label.

Effective labeling requires more than a clear symbol; interested consumers must have access to more information about a technology that they find interesting. It is impossible to include such information on food labels, which are already small and difficult to read, but accurate information about the genetically engineered crops available in the United States should be easy for curious consumers to find. Canola, field corn, cotton, soybean, sugar beet, apple, sweet corn, papaya, potato, and squash each need a separate page on the USDA website explaining the GE technology present in these crops in an accessible way. This provides consumers with a starting place to learn more about genetic engineering if they are interested, and consumers can be linked to these pages by a QR code on food labels.

Finally, labeling must be ubiquitous. Part of the uncertainty about genetic engineering technologies comes from its apparent rarity. To date, most genetic engineering has focused on agronomic traits like insect resistance that benefit farmers, rather than end-use quality traits like color that are obvious to consumers. This makes genetic engineering largely invisible in the grocery store. Most consumers have no idea that a vast majority of the high fructose corn syrup in our favorite sugary snacks is made from genetically modified field corn, and this lends itself to the stigma around GMOs and genetic engineering as a technology. All crops that contain any level of genetic engineering above the 0.9% threshold proposed by the USDA should be labeled, as should products and crop derivatives made from genetically engineered crops. Genetic modification is ubiquitous and an important part of modern agriculture. Demonstrating the extent to which genetic engineering has been involved in producing popular products will help destigmatize a technology that has the potential to benefit U.S. producers and consumers alike.

Maximizing consumer information and understanding should be the standard for any kind of food disclosure requirement or regulation.

In the case of bioengineered food, wise consumers would want to know the name of each bioengineered ingredient, and the year that each specific bioengineering process was invented, developed, and approved for market.

Some consumers would want more information about the processes themselves, and a website listed on food labels could lead consumers to more in-depth information. Labels for food items such as fruit, vegetables, and others sold unpackaged could be provided as display signage.

I have been sailing for 35 years on everything from unlimited tonnage ships on the open ocean to limited tonnage vessels running rivers.  I have served as a AB, Mate, and Master.  Every 5 years I have completed this class in roughly two (2) hours.  Everyone else in the class also finished in the same short amount of time.  This shows that for mariners who regularly use a radar, the refresher class is a waste of time and money.  The few people Ive known who could not effetely use a radar had so many other faults, they should never have received a license in the first place.  I do agree with the requirement for the class for those personnel whom have not been actively using the radar.  Their skills could indeed become rusty, and the refresher can be useful should they wind up out from behind a desk and back on the bridge.

I am against using any "cute" icons or logos, instead favor the letters "GMO" or the word "Bioengineered" in a circle or oval be used.

Changing the now well known phrase "GMO" to "bioengineered" is in my opinion just an attempt to deceive the consumers who would otherwise reject a GMO labeled product.

After seeing the new GMO branding I feel like Alice who fell down the rabbit hole and landed in a poor version of the Emperor's New Clothes. Please remember that this decision to rebrand will greatly affect the people of this planet. We all deserve to clearly and easily know what has been done to the food we eat, including genetic manipulation. Please Don't give in to this pretty new book cover... the contents are so important.The attempt to hide the label GMO, which is the term most of the world is now familiar with, is a travesty.
We as Americans have the right to know exactly what is in our food.  And to achieve that we have the right to have accurate labeling on all food products.

I am a parent and consumer of food in this country. I urge the USDA to provide clear, on-package labeling of foods that contain ingredients made from genetically engineered crops, regardless of the specific type of technology used. Any food made with ingredients that were genetically engineered by any method should be labeled as such.

I already buy the bulk of my food from small family farms and ranchers around me because of the regulatory agencies manipulative marketing tactics and labeling. This new proposed labeling method will just push me and people like me over the edge to stop shopping packaged foods altogether. Instead of fooling more people into buying GMO products because that's what this is really about, this new labeling will do the opposite because there are a lot more educated and aware people out there then our regulatory agencies think.

Such deception from a government agency should not be tolerated. Really? A sun with a smiley face? It's like putting cartoons and rainbows on cereal boxes. If the USDA's intention is to make us all sicker and fatter then this new labeling is a great idea. However, that is not my hope for our country. So please, reconsider this new rule and seriously realign your goals with that of health, not illness.

Clear product and package labeling is essential, not the use of QR codes or enhanced UPC codes. Dump the smiley face BE logo and replace it with something more objective. The USDAs labeling regulations must cover ALL forms of genetic engineering. I Want Full Disclosure with GMO Food Labeling.

Our company is a Tier 1 automotive supplier based in metro Detroit. It supplies antenna systems ranging from infotainment like AM/FM and SXM, to safety products including 4G/LTE, GPS and now DSRC for vehicle to vehicle (V2V) or vehicle to infrastructure (V2X) technologies. The HTSUS Subheading for antennas is 8529.10.91. (Other antennas and antenna reflectors of all kinds and parts, for use)

Its manufacturing strategy since 2014 is to localize development and production in the region vehicles are manufactured. Over 90% of its products are produced in North America for vehicles manufactured in North and South America. However, there are products still produced in China for current US manufactured vehicles. It has been beneficial to keep manufacturing in China so that US manufactured vehicles can remain competitive. Increasing tariffs on these goods would not provide more jobs for the US. It would likely cause manufacturers to find alternative regions to produce these products.

More importantly, the North American operations are focusing more on the technologies needed for future vehicles. These technologies include 4G, 5G and V2V communication, higher accuracy GPS, emergency call, and collision avoidance. They require highly technical personnel for development and manufacturing. While we continue to develop high technology products, we believe that production in China benefits the US economy by keeping US vehicle manufacturing, especially entry class vehicles competitive.

text:
I would like to comment on the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) Notice: H-1B Petitions Filed on Behalf of Nurses. As a Baccalaureate prepared Registered nurse who holds national certification in adult critical care (CCRN) and is now in the process of earning a Doctorate of Nursing Practice (DNP) degree with a focus in nurse anesthesia, I can personally attest to the tremendous value nurses who meet the criteria for H-1B status bring to the healthcare workforce. The Institute of Medicines (IOM) 2010 landmark report on the future of nursing emphasized the imperative nature of drastically expanding the number of nurses educated at both the Baccalaureate and Doctoral level, while simultaneously preparing nurses to care for an increasingly diverse patient population (IOM, 2010). Nurses qualifying for H-1B status are ideally positioned to meet this charge.
While didactic nursing education and real world clinical experience are not entirely mutually exclusive domains, each contribute in a complementary manner to high-quality cost-effective patient care outcomes. A myriad of publications demonstrate the link between reduced patient mortality and failure to rescue rates with higher proportions of Baccalaureate prepared and specialty certified nursing staff (AACN, 2017). Furthermore, given the current shortages in the nursing workforce and projected 16% growth required to keep pace with the increase in demand for nursing services (~1.09 million nurses by 2024), turning away well qualified, experienced nurses is simply too great an expense for the already overburdened healthcare system to incur (AACN, 2017).

References

American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN). (2017). Nursing shortage fact sheet. Retrieved from http://www.aacnnursing.org/News-Information/Fact-Sheets/Nursing-Shortage

Institute of Medicine (IOM). (2010). The future of nursing: Leading change, advancing health. Washington, D.C.: The National Academies Press. doi: 10.17226/12956

Could that be what caused his cancer all Those years ago!!! Has he now been exposed to the same chemicals!!!!! Please help us clean our water and make our town, our state, our country have Clean safe water!! Dont let these companies tell us what to do!! Filter our water filter our poor childrens water!!! Please help us understand what these chemicals have done to us, done to our Children! We requested they filter out schools water and they said "NO" ! i don't see how that goes long with their commitment to communities!
Hep us to help make it better for us and them in the future!!!! I am asking to regulate aII PFCs even the ones we are still Iearnign about. don't make us be Iab rats any more. Make the limits under 1 ug.

docAbstract:
Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) is a category of man-made chemicals that have been widely used to make products because of their stain-resistant, waterproof and/or nonstick properties. These chemicals can be very persistent in the environment and in the human body – meaning they don’t break down quickly and they can accumulate over time. There is evidence that exposure to PFAS can lead to adverse health outcomes in humans.

Additional information: https://www.epa.gov/pfas 

EPA is committed to supporting states, tribes and local communities in addressing challenges with PFAS.  As a part of this effort, EPA is taking action to identify solutions to address PFAS in the environment.

EPA is hosting a National Leadership Summit on May 22nd and May 23rd to aid in identifying solutions to address PFAS challenges in drinking water and at contaminated sites. Following the meeting, EPA plans to visit states with communities impacted by PFAS to further engage on ways the agency can best support the work that’s being done at the state, local and tribal levels. Using information from the National Summit and community engagements, EPA plans to develop a PFAS Management Plan for release later this year.

EPA provides the opportunity for the public to submit input on how EPA can best help states and communities facing this issue. EPA will consider comments as the agency plans next steps.

text:
To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing today to submit my comment on the Food and Drug Administration's (FDA's) possible new rule concerning the nicotine levels in cigarettes. By mandating that the levels of nicotine be reduced nearly 98 percent, this possible rule would essentially ban all cigarettes on the market today. This possible rule is unfair to adult smokers, and may not even be achievable. The FDA should not move forward without considering the impact it would have on adult smokers as well as our larger economy.

Once again, the government is trying to solve a problem by restricting choice rather than by giving adults more alternatives. Rather than reduce choice for adult smokers, the FDA should focus on giving adult smokers more options and access to a wider choice of less harmful tobacco products, and truthful, accurate information about the benefits of switching to them. Instead, this de facto ban would simply target adult smokers for purchasing the legal products they prefer.

FDA should focus resources on a comprehensive plan to reduce harm through proven strategies to prevent initiation, encourage cessation and by fostering the development of reduced risk alternatives to cigarettes that are satisfying to adult smokers.

Please do not consider such a severe and unfair proposal.

docAbstract: The Department of Justice anticipates issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that would interpret the statutory definition of “machinegun” in the National Firearms Act of 1934 and Gun Control Act of 1968 to clarify whether certain devices, commonly known as “bump fire” stocks, fall within that definition. Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

text:
On the night of October 1, 2017, a gunman opened fire from a hotel room on the 32nd floor of the Mandalay Bay hotel into the 22,000 person crowd at the Route 91 Harvest country music festival in Las Vegas, Nevada, killing 58 people and injuring more than 500. The gunman fired more than 1,100 rounds of ammunition in 11 minutes, using semi-automatic rifles modified with dangerous firearm accessories designed to dramatically accelerate the rate of gunfire, commonly known as bump fire stocks.



These devices are intended to circumvent the restrictions on possession of fully automatic firearms in the Gun Control Act of 1968 and the National Firearms Act of 1934 by allowing an individual to modify a semiautomatic rifle in such a manner that it operates with a similar rate of fire as a fully automatic rifle, posing a substantial risk to public safety.



In the absence of immediate action by Congress, I urge ATF to finalize its proposed rule clarifying that bump fire stocks, along with other conversion devices that enable semiautomatic weapons to mimic automatic fire, qualify as machine guns under the National Firearms Act. And then Congress must act as wellto ensure that manufacturers cannot continue to endanger public safety by designing devices that imitate machine guns and subvert the law.



The continued presence of these dangerous devices puts all of our communities at risk, and both Congress and ATF must take action quickly to address this threat.
